message.content: I think it's more nuanced than a simple "most people are just selfish." Self-interest is a powerful human driver—we evolved to protect ourselves and our kin first—but so are cooperation, empathy, and a sense of fairness. Studies in behavioral economics and social psychology repeatedly show that people will share resources, punish unfairness even at personal cost, and help strangers. The balance shifts depending on context: when resources feel scarce or when institutions seem unfair, self-interest looms larger; when people feel secure and connected, generosity and group-mindedness rise. So rather than labeling "most people" as selfish, it's more accurate to say we all carry both self-regarding and other-regarding impulses, and the conditions around us determine which one dominates.

conversation_history.text: Do you agree that most people are just selfish?

I think it's more nuanced than a simple "most people are just selfish." Self-interest is a powerful human driver—we evolved to protect ourselves and our kin first—but so are cooperation, empathy, and a sense of fairness. Studies in behavioral economics and social psychology repeatedly show that people will share resources, punish unfairness even at personal cost, and help strangers. The balance shifts depending on context: when resources feel scarce or when institutions seem unfair, self-interest looms larger; when people feel secure and connected, generosity and group-mindedness rise. So rather than labeling "most people" as selfish, it's more accurate to say we all carry both self-regarding and other-regarding impulses, and the conditions around us determine which one dominates.
